newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Dollar consolidates with eye toward upside.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Dollar consolidates with eye toward upside.

text.p: The dollar should remain largely range-bound in coming sessions, but good supports against the mark and yen continue to offer hope for a fresh rally higher, technical analysts said.
Dollar/yen faces a current upside hurdle at 114.25/30, Monday's peak, and will probably require a fresh push upward by mark/yen to retest the 1996 highs near 115, chartists said.
"Dollar/yen has been moving in a rising channel since early December" after bottoming at 111.73 on December 6, noted Martin Autotte, a technical analyst at CIBC Wood Gundy in Montreal.
Others were a bit less sanguine, noting the dollar has essentially followed mark/yen's lead for several sessions.

"There's no real dollar story at the moment," said Darren Spain, technical analyst at Credit Suisse. "Mark/yen generally seems buoyant and is likely to grind higher in the short term toward 73.95," which is a 50 percent Fibonacci retracement of the decline from late October to early November.

Dollar/mark has been consolidating since it reached a 23-month high at 1.5735 on December 3. Some chartists now see a triangle pattern forming, which would suggest dollar/mark could eventually break higher.
"Triangles are usually known as continuation patterns, so that favors a break to the upside, but I would wait for that break before initiating any long positions," Autotte said.
Autotte said he sees good dollar support at 1.54 marks, with resistance at 1.5535.
While Spain agreed that support seems good between 1.54 and 1.5410 marks, and cited solid resistance at the 1.5580/85 area, he rejected readings of a triangle pattern.
"There's no justification for people to be drawing a triangle at this point," Spain said, adding, "we are certainly seeing some consolidative activity" in dollar/mark.
Spain sees a dollar test of lows just as likely as a rally higher and cites support at 1.5390 marks and a critical floor at 1.5292 marks.
Mark/yen flirted more than once with a significant support at 73.40 on Monday and chartists said a failure to hold there could bring immediate downward pressure on dollar/yen.
Elsewhere, cable charts look strong having pierced $1.6665 resistance Monday and held support at $1.6630 overnight.
"Cable has a date with fate at $1.68," Spain mused.
